oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery On The Record with Dolly Parton - Part 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Dolly Parton (performer) for Ralph Emery: On the Record With Dolly Parton. Tape features a performance from Chet Atkins (performer). Recording is performed in front of a live audience. Recording is from September 29, 1994. Tape is labeled part 1.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Dolly Parton; Chet Atkins
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:19) Ralph Emery introduces Dolly Parton, and both discuss Parton's decision to release a book -- (03:11) Emery praises the spirituality of the book, and Parton dedicates her strength to god -- (04:07) Emery invites Parton to reflect on the plastic surgery she has had performed -- (06:31) Emery invites Parton to sing "Me and Little Andy" -- (07:08) Emery invites to describe who Aunt Martha Williams is -- (09:50) Emery and Parton joke about how Parton came to be born on January 19, 1946 -- (10:41)Emery invites Parton to reflect on her story about stones being placed in soup; additionally, Parton describes the purpose of "Coat of Many Colors" -- (14:44) Emery reveals Parton's second book, and Parton readdresses "Coat of Many Colors" -- (15:53) Parton lists off all of her sibling's names before Emery inquires about Parton's childhood home -- (17:59) Emery addresses Parton's colorful neighbor Sawdust -- (20:20) Emery and Parton praise Robert Lee Parton's paternal nature, and Parton reveals how Robert Lee did not like lizards -- (23:15) Emery inquires about how Robert Lee had worked on his farm -- (24:21) Parton discusses how she never was a fan of schooling -- (25:08) Emery and Parton discuss how Parton received a break on the Cas Walker Show in Knoxville, Tennessee -- (28:55) Parton recalls how Cas Walker began to bring her to public appearances and a grease pole -- (32:01) Emery and Parton joke about Robert Lee's trigger finger -- (32:58) Parton reveals she was laughed at when she told her high school she was moving to Nashville -- (34:30) Parton discusses how she used to be starving when she moved to Nashville -- (37:10) Emery reveals Emery was introduced to Parton through Carl and Pearl Butler -- (40:00) Emery introduces "Put it Off Until Tomorrow," and Parton reveals that a number of disc jockeys attributed the song to Parton -- (41:49) Emery inquires to Parton's duration with Fred Foster -- (43:01) Emery reflects on Porter Wagoner hearing "Dumb Blonde," and Emery introduces RCA's Chet Atkins -- (43:56) Emery introduces the commercial break -- (45:18) Chet Atkins practices the guitar while Parton leads the crowd to follow along -- (49:03) Emery asks Atkins to recall how Parton came into his life -- (51:01) Emery askings Atkins to remember to the first time Atkins performed with Parton; additionally, Parton reflects on her recording with Wagoner -- (54:16) Longer Than Always [featuring Chet Atkins] (Dolly Parton) -- (57:28) Emery, Parton, and Atkins joke about how Atkins sued Parton -- (59:51) Emery says his thanks to Atkins, and Atkins praises Parton before a commercial break
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Parton, Dolly; Atkins, Chet;
